Republican presidential candidates will converge in Iowa for the Republican Party of Iowa’s Growth and Opportunity Event on Saturday. While the candidates have made many trips across the state, this event provides Iowans the opportunity to see them in one place and ask about their policies. Immigration reform is a policy area most Republican candidates have yet to address in a concrete and pragmatic way. If we can muster the political will, immigration reform is an opportunity for Republicans to improve the economy and people’s lives at the same time. As a Republican, I do not believe a majority of our party supports the extreme views on mass deportation that some candidates advocate. Mass deportation would require increased taxes and a massive growth in government that would hurt our economy. According to some studies, deportation could cost taxpayers $400-600 billion. Growing government and spending up to $600 billion is not a conservative solution. As candidates campaign across Iowa in the coming weeks, we need to encourage them to propose meaningful and realistic plans to fix our broken immigration system. Voters are listening.
— Kevin McLaughlin, Des Moines
RICHMOND, Va. (AP) -- Virginia Republicans have maintained control of the state Senate after scoring key victories in Tuesday's legislative elections.

Republicans were able to hold off well-financed Democratic candidates in a handful of competitive districts, allowing the GOP to keep control of both chambers of the General Assembly and remain a potent foil to Democratic Gov. Terry McAuliffe's legislative priorities.
ELECTION RESULTS: Check back here to see updates on the races

Republican state Sen. Frank Wagner has defeated Democrat Gary McCollum in state Senate contest that Republicans needed to help keep control of the upper chamber. Wagner was ahead of McCollum 55 percent to 45 percent with 82 percent of the vote counted.
The Virginia Beach contest was one of the state's most expensive, and pit McCollum, a cable executive, against Wagner, a former shipyard owner.

State Sen. Lynwood Lewis has defeated Republican challenger Richard Ottinger in state Senate contest that Democrats needed to win as they try and regain control of the upper chamber. Lewis was ahead of Ottinger 57 percent to 42 percent with 59 percent of the vote counted. Senate District 6 includes parts of Hampton Roads, a portion of the middle peninsula and all of the Eastern Shore.
Click here for a list of candidates
In the House, the GOP maintained a clear advantage.

Democrats will maintain control over the District 93 seat in Virginia's House of Delegates. Democratic Del. Monty Mason was beating Republican Lara Overy with 57 percent of the vote with 88 percent of the precincts reporting Tuesday. Overy had 43 percent of the vote. Mason, a Williamsburg resident who works in fraud protection for Visa, Inc., has held the seat since 2014. Overy serves as director of development at Thomas Nelson Community College. District 93 includes Williamsburg and parts of Newport News, James City and York Counties. The district has leaned Democratic in recent elections.

With Republicans maintaining control of the General Assembly, Democratic Gov. Terry McAuliffe lost a chance to gain leverage when negotiating with GOP lawmakers on matters like the state budget during the last two years of his term. And his top legislative priorities, like expanding Medicaid coverage to the state's poor or enacting tighter gun laws, remain out of reach.

McAuliffe led a well-financed effort, with help from deep-pocketed donors and billionaire former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg's gun control group, to help Democrats in a handful of competitive races.
WHAT HAVE BEEN KEY ISSUES?

Off-year elections with no statewide candidates on the ballot, such as Tuesday's election, have historically had low turnouts. Consequently, both parties have tried to tailor their messages to appeal to their respective bases.
For Democrats, they've attacked Republicans as being unfriendly to women's health issues, and irresponsibly rigid on gun control.
Republicans have accused McAuliffe of supporting unreasonably high tolls and blasted other Democrats as being unfriendly toward Virginia's coal industry.
The turnout in Virginia Beach was around 22% Tuesday.
WHO FUNDED THE CAMPAIGNS?
Virginia has no limits on campaign donations, and much of the current election cycle has been funded by rich out-of-state individuals and large corporations.

Former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg's gun control group has announced spending $2.2 million to help two Democratic candidates in competitive Senate races. And large donors to the governor's political action committee or the Democratic Party of Virginia include a Democratic mega donor from New York and one of McAuliffe's law school friends from Florida.

Republicans have been helped largely by the Republican State Leadership Committee, a national GOP group largely funded by corporate interests. Its recent large donors have included Wal-Mart, General Motors and tobacco giant Reynolds American.

In the state, several of Virginia's most powerful corporations and special interests continued to be major campaign donors. They include associations representing dentists, auto dealers and beer wholesalers, as well as energy company Dominion Resources Inc.
Voters can also find information about the election, including what's on their ballot, by clicking here or calling the Department of Elections toll-free at (800) 552-9745.
Bobby Jindal has a list of people he has issues with, and he explained them all during a stop at Simpson College in Indianola Thursday night.
The Louisiana Governor's immediate focus was on Democrat Hillary Clinton.

Jindal told a crowd of about 80 that Clinton’s campaign is running ads and trying to make money off the Benghazi scandal, but Americans need to remember at the heart of the controversy is four dead Americans.

But Democrats weren’t the only ones on his attack list. He added: “I don’t have a famous last name. My daddy wasn’t president. I don’t have a reality TV show. Here’s what I do have. I have the backbone and bandwidth to get us through this.”
He said the next president will be sitting across from a Putin or an Ayatollah, and they better not need a teleprompter to get through conversations.

Jindal said just electing any Republican isn’t good enough. He said he doesn't agree with Jeb Bush, who said the Republicans have to be willing to lose the primary in order to win the general election.

“I want to translate that. That is the establishment telling us to hide our conservative beliefs and principles to try to get the left and the media to like you,” Jindal said. “That never works. If we do that again, we will deserve to lose again. This country doesn’t need us to become a second liberal party or a cheap version of the Democratic Party. Why don’t we do something different for a change? Why don’t we embrace our own principles? That’s a radical idea.”

The President and the United States Supreme Court were also on Jindal’s list of poor decision makers. He said the United States has a foreign policy that allows it to treat its friends like dirt and its enemies to walk all over it.

“He’s declared a war on trans-fats and a truce with Iran,” Jindal said about Obama. “I’ve got a deal for him. I’ll protect my kids from Oreos and Twinkies if he’ll do his job and protect us from radical Islamic terrorists.
“We’ve got a Supreme Court that thinks they’re smarter than God when it comes to defining marriage,” Jindal said.

His negative statements also blanketed the entire D.C. establishment as he said he'd be for term limits. The only way that can happen, Jindal said, is if American voters remind their congressmen if they don't vote for term limits they won't earn their seat back the next election anyway.
"The idea of America is slipping away from us. Shame on those fools in DC who are giving away the idea of America," Jindal said. "And shame on us if we’re letting them do it."
WASHINGTON — You know the conventional wisdom that governors are the ones who tend to fare best as presidential candidates?
Not so for Scott Walker and Rick Perry.

In a record-sized Republican field, the first two contenders to call it quits are, surprisingly, Wisconsin Gov. Walker — the first governor in history to survive a recall election, and one with swing-state credentials — and former Texas governor Perry, the longest-serving chief executive in Lone Star history.

Leading the GOP field in the new CNN/ORC Poll are celebrity billionaire Donald Trump, retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson and former CEO Carly Fiorina — three outsiders who among them have never won an election.

Here's what the political analysts say this means, although given our track record this year, you might want to take it with a grain of salt. At the end of the day, the 2016 Republican nominee is still likely to be someone who actually has held office before. That makes the narrowing of the field good news for former Florida governor Jeb Bush, Texas Sen. Ted Cruz, Ohio Gov. John Kasich and Florida Sen. Marco Rubio.

It demonstrates that money isn't everything, although the fact that Walker and Perry were having trouble raising money was a factor in their decisions. Carson and Fiorina haven't been seen as particularly big fundraisers, something we'll know for sure after the next Federal Election Commission reports are due next month. Their rising standings are likely to make it easier to feed their campaign coffers.

And it underscores the power of the debates. Strong performances by Fiorina have been the single biggest factor propelling her from the undercard event at the first debate to Trump's top challenger after the second one.

Walker never managed to break into the main conversation in either debate. He gained political fame nationwide by taking on the public-employee unions in Wisconsin, and his poll ratings soared after a strong early speech at the Iowa Freedom Summit in January. But he didn't seem sure-footed in addressing national-security questions, and he faced questions about consistency when he changed position on issues such as birthright citizenship.

In Madison, Wis., on Monday, he said he was suspending his campaign and encouraged his former rivals to do the same "so that the voters can focus on a limited number of candidates who can offer a positive conservative alternative to the current front-runner." That presumably was a reference to Trump, although Walker didn't mention him by name.

The next GOP debate, hosted by CNBC, is scheduled to take place at the University of Colorado Boulder in five weeks. The Democratic field may be about to get bigger, with the possible addition of Vice President Biden. But the Republican field just got smaller, and not because any of the outsiders decided to call it a day.
Republicans ran the table locally in major judicial races, winning all four open state Supreme Court seats as well as the newly created Monroe County Family Court judgeship.

Winning the four state Supreme Court judgeships were Ontario County Court Judge Craig Doran, Monroe County Court Judge James Piampiano, Pittsford Town Justice Bill Taylor, and local lawyer Judy Sinclair.
Local lawyer Matthew Nafus, who was the only Democrat who campaigned for most of the year, finished fifth. He was significantly outspent by Republicans in the largely GOP district.
Local attorney James Vazzana defeated Maritza Buitrago for the new Family Court seat that was created by the state Legislature to help handle the court's burgeoning caseload.
Complete election coverage
Election results

With retirements and the movement of a judge to a new position, the state Supreme Court had an unusually high number of openings this year with the four open judgeships. In a judicial district which encompasses eight counties, Democrats have long had a difficult time winning judicial elections in election years without national elections on the ballot.

Doran, 51, is a former state assemblyman who has been the administrative judge for the 7th Judicial District. Piampiano, 65, was a Henrietta town justice before his election to Monroe County Court. Taylor, 40, is a deputy county attorney with Monroe County and a Pittsford town justice and Sinclair, 50, is a defense lawyer in the law office of Thomas Cook, which largely handles drunken driving offenses.
Doran said he hopes to continue as administrative judge, a position appointed by New York's chief judge.
"It's an overwhelming feeling of honor and responsibility and I'm grateful for the support I received," he said of his electoral win Tuesday.
Democrats Deborah Indivino, Jo Anne Leegant and Ella Van Loon also ran, though their nominations were viewed as a political step by many.
State Supreme Court justices serve 14-year terms. There is a mandatory retirement age of 70, though they can be appointed for up to three two-year terms after that age.

Vazzana, 50, is a lawyer in the law firm of Chamberlain, D'Amanda, Oppenheimer & Greenfield. During the campaign, he stressed his work in matrimonial courts and Family Court and said he wants to improve the efficiency of Family Court.
Buitrago is a Monroe County public defender who practices in Family Court.
Family Court judges serve 10-year terms.
GCRAIG@Gannett.com
Republican leaders in the Indiana Senate say they plan to introduce a measure as early as Tuesday intended to enhance civil rights protections for gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender people.
But the measure will also include additional protections for religious freedom.

“I can just tell you that there’ll be strong language in there for both civil rights and for religious freedom, and so we’ll just leave it at that,” Senate President Pro Tempore David Long said Monday during an Indiana Chamber of Commerce 2016 legislative preview event. “We’re trying to do our best to get a balanced piece of legislation.”

He declined to provide additional details until the measure can be shared with Senate Republicans on Tuesday, when lawmakers meet at the Statehouse for Organization Day in preparation for the 2016 legislative session that begins in January.
Long, R-Fort Wayne, promised a hearing on the measure and said Sen. Travis Holdman, a Markle Republican, would carry it.
Holdman also declined to give details. He told The Star he expected to file the bill Tuesday afternoon.

Efforts to expand protections for LGBT Hoosiers have been underway since March, when lawmakers passed and Gov. Mike Pence signed Indiana’s Religious Freedom Restoration Act. The law sets a judicial standard to weigh religious objections, but opponents feared it would allow business owners to deny services to gays and lesbians for religious reasons. Boycotts and event cancellations followed.
The furor subsided when Pence and the Republican-controlled General Assembly amended the law to say it could not be used to discriminate against LGBT Hoosiers.

But gay rights advocates, Democrats and powerful business interests including the Indiana Chamber say adding sexual orientation and gender identity to state laws banning discrimination in employment, housing and public accommodation are necessary to fully restore the state’s reputation as a welcoming place.
But those looking for an unqualified expansion of those protections are unlikely to find a strong advocate in Holdman, who has traditionally been conservative on social issues.

He filed a bill during the 2015 session that would have allowed some state contractors to discriminate in hiring based on religion. That measure would have allowed religious-affiliated organizations that receive state contracts — including hospitals, universities, and childcare providers — to hire people based on their religion. It also would have allowed those organizations to require employees to follow religious tenets.
The measure passed in the Senate but failed to advance in the House amid the controversy over RFRA.

Democrats, including presumptive gubernatorial candidate John Gregg, have said restoring the state's reputation after RFRA requires adding just four words — "sexual orientation" and "gender identity" — and a comma to the state's civil rights laws.
Long said that's an oversimplification.

“Anyone who says that is short changing the discussion here,” he said. “The freedom of religion in our United States Constitution and certainly in the Indiana Constitution is on the same level as freedom of speech, freedom of the press and freedom of association. It’s that important. We should not discount that as we discuss how do we deal with this issue of whether you expand protected class status to sexual orientation and gender identity.”

But any such measure is likely to face a long road in the General Assembly. House Speaker Brian Bosma, R-Indianapolis, declined Monday to guarantee a hearing on the measure if it makes it over from the Senate.

“This is clearly the toughest issue of the session,” he said. “It may be the toughest issue of any of our careers. We have to balance two very deeply held interests in Indiana. First of all, Hoosiers do not abide by discrimination, and secondly, Hoosiers value freedom of conscience and religious liberty.”
That tension around the issue is likely to be on full display Tuesday at the Statehouse.
The Indiana Pastors Alliance and other religious conservatives are planning a prayer session in the North Atrium of the Statehouse at 10 a.m. on Tuesday, followed by a rally at 2 p.m.

Meanwhile, faith leaders affiliated with Freedom Indiana, a group seeking expanded LGBT protections, plan to deliver 5,000 letters of support to lawmakers at 9:15 a.m., with a noon rally on the Statehouse steps.
Call Star reporter Tony Cook at (317) 444-6081. Follow him on Twitter: @indystartony.
CLINTON, Ia. — Hillary Clinton told Iowans Sunday that although she knows it would be hard, she believes she could forge compromises with congressional Republicans to get important measures passed.

“You do have to be something of an optimist to run for president. Otherwise, I don’t know how you’d get out of bed in the morning,” she said to chuckles from the more than 400 people who came to see her at Clinton Middle School. “You’ve got to believe that you’ll be able to get things done. And I certainly do, because I’ve seen it.”

The Democratic candidate for president and front-runner said she watched her husband, Bill, accomplish things when he was president. “I think it’s fair to say the Republicans gave him a lot of trouble, so it wasn’t easy. But you get up every day and you do it.”
She also touted her work as first lady, in the U.S. Senate and as secretary of state.

Clinton repeated her refrain that she would work to find common ground while knowing when to stand her ground. “If you only talk to or work with people you agree with, you will forget that much of the world may not have the same views,” she said. "… Compromise is not a dirty word in a democracy. If you think you have all the answers, you probably belong in some other system."
The country's founders made all kinds of compromises with each other, she said. "They did it because they recognized that no one of us has a total of understanding of everything."
Also visit: DesMoinesRegister.com/IowaCaucuses | Candidate tracker and calendar in Iowa | Sign up for Caucuses Newsletter
The candidate expressed her thoughts in response to two Iowans who asked her Sunday about her ability to push through compromises in the country’s difficult political climate.

Retired teacher El Ivens of De Witt was in the audience listening to the discussion. She said afterward that she shares others’ concerns about how hard it can be for U.S. leaders to reach compromise. She thought Clinton gave a good answer. “I’d like to think she’d be in a position to get things done,” she said.

Ivens, 63, had been leaning toward supporting Clinton in the Feb. 1 caucuses. The candidate’s appearance here Sunday sealed the deal. Ivens said she was impressed with Clinton’s give-and-take with multiple voters here. “She was so much more human than she was eight years ago,” when she wound up coming in third in the Iowa caucuses.

If she becomes president, Clinton would need at least some Republican support to pass many of her proposals. On Sunday, she touted a new one: a plan to help families who are caring for ill or disabled loved ones.

The plan includes new tax credits of up to $1,200 to help families offset up to $6,000 annually in costs associated with caring for parents or grandparents at home. She also would let such people count their caregiving time toward their Social Security retirement benefits. Now, she said, too many people, especially women, get shortchanged on Social Security because they have to temporarily drop out of the workforce to care for relatives.
“Providing care for a loved one should not mean sacrificing your own secure retirement,” she said.
She also proposed new assistance to encourage people to go into caregiving professions and stay in those jobs, which often have huge turnover due to low wages and stressful conditions.
Shortly after Clinton finished speaking, national Republican Party spokesman Fred Brown suggested his party would not jump to compromise on her caregiver proposal.

“Hillary Clinton's solution to every pressing policy issue is to expand government and raise taxes, and this plan is no different as it will cost hardworking Americans billions. Clinton is simply checking a box to score political points at the expense of middle-class Americans," Brown wrote in a news release.

WASHINGTON — Indiana’s House members split Wednesday over a two-year budget deal that would extend the debt limit, boost spending and provide a respite from the fiscal brinkmanship that has gripped Washington in recent years.

The agreement, passed after an hourlong debate and a last-minute scramble for votes, would increase federal spending by about $80 billion over the next two years, with the new money evenly divided between military and nonmilitary programs. It also would extend the nation’s borrowing limit through March 2017, when a new Congress and a new president are in place.

The deal cleared the House 266-167, with Democrats — including Indiana Reps. Andre Carson, of Indianapolis, and Pete Visclosky, of Merrillville — providing the bulk of the yes votes. Every Democrat voted for the bill.
Rep. Susan Brooks, of Carmel, and Luke Messer, of Shelbyville, were the only Indiana Republicans to vote for the deal.

Brooks said in a statement that her top concern is “to govern in a responsible way that will lead to debt reduction in the long term.” The deal doesn't add to the deficit, eases an increase in Medicare premiums facing millions of seniors and “averts a dangerous default that would threaten our economy,” she said.
Most House Republicans voted no, including Indiana Reps. Jackie Walorski, Marlin Stutzman, Todd Rokita, Larry Bucshon and Todd Young.
Rokita, R-Indianapolis, said he’s opposed to raising the debt limit unless changes are made to expensive entitlement programs such as Medicare and Medicaid.
“The legislation that the House passed today stunts our progress toward meaningful spending reform,” he said in a statement.

House Speaker John Boehner, R-Ohio, and others hailed the measure, saying it was a fiscally responsible proposal that would restore order to Washington’s budget process and allow Congress to provide fresh investments in military and domestic programs alike.

Boehner quietly negotiated the agreement with the White House and other congressional leaders, unveiling it Monday night as he prepared to resign his speakership and leave Congress. The Senate is expected to take up the measure soon, although a final vote might not come until Monday.

Sen. Rand Paul, R-Ky., who is running for president, said he will filibuster the measure. "I will do everything I can do to stop it,” Paul told reporters in Colorado, where he was campaigning ahead of Wednesday’s GOP presidential debate.
Although Paul could delay the measure’s passage, it’s unlikely he would be able to derail it. The Senate can end a filibuster with 60 votes.

The deal would ease spending caps put in place by the 2011 Budget Control Act, which called for across-the-board cuts to government programs. It would give lawmakers an extra $50 billion to spend on federal programs in the first year and $30 billion the year after.

"We’re going to be able to make some vital investments in key areas," including education, scientific research and military readiness, said Rep. Chris Van Hollen, D-Md., the top Democrat on the House Budget Committee.

In addition, the agreement would reduce a predicted spike in the cost of Medicare premiums for some seniors next year and would make changes to Social Security — particularly its disability program — to achieve $168 billion in long-term savings. The measure would be paid for with a mix of tax and policy changes, including a provision to sell 58 million barrels of oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve between 2018 and 2025.
Critics derided it as an eleventh-hour agreement that handed President Barack Obama and congressional Democrats a big spending victory.

“Another last-minute, back-room spending deal by the White House and congressional leaders that busts the budget caps and allows unlimited debt for the next 18 months,” said Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio. “No wonder so many Americans distrust Congress.”

The budget deal takes several thorny fiscal issues off the plate of Boehner’s expected successor, Rep. Paul Ryan, R-Wis. Without the agreement, the nation would have reached its borrowing limit Tuesday, and funding for the government would have expired Dec. 11.
Ryan voted for the deal, even as he criticized the secret negotiations that produced it.
"As with any budget agreement, this one has some good, some bad and some ugly," Ryan said in a statement Wednesday. But he acknowledged it would help him start with a clean slate.

"What has been produced will go a long way toward relieving the uncertainty hanging over us," he said. "It’s time for us to turn the page on the last few years and get to work on a bold agenda that we can take to the American people."
Paul Singer of USA TODAY contributed to this story.
Email Maureen Groppe at mgroppe@gannett.com. Follow her on Twitter: @mgroppe.

DES MOINES — Donald Trump's appeal cuts across several of the Republican Party's various and often divergent factions, attracting pluralities of both tea party and establishment voters to his candidacy.
That surprising development, revealed in the latest Des Moines Register/Bloomberg Politics Iowa Poll, helps explain his lead in the race for Iowa's first-in-the-nation presidential caucuses.

The billionaire businessman and media personality is the top choice for 30% of Iowa Republicans who identify with the tea party movement, 30% of business-oriented establishment Republicans and 16% of Christian conservatives.

"To a certain extent, it seems people see in Trump what they want to see," said J. Ann Selzer, the pollster for the Register/Bloomberg poll. "He's thin on issue positions on purpose. Tea party supporters see him as anti-establishment. Business-oriented people see him the consummate businessman. And Christian conservatives see him as a man who says the Bible is his favorite book — even ahead of his bestselling Art of the Deal."
Overall, 23% of likely Republican caucus attendees call Trump their No. 1 choice, putting him 5 percentage points ahead of second-place Ben Carson.

And on top of that, his popularity among Republican activists appears to be surging: 61% of respondents report favorable feelings about him. That's a 34-percentage-point spike since the last Iowa Poll in May, and it moves his popularity into positive territory after months underwater.
Several poll respondents said they appreciate Trump's status as a political outsider and his ability to force the discussion on difficult or impolitic issues.

"He's not a career politician, he's a businessman, and my God, the way things are going in this country I think it'd be great to have a businessman in the presidency," said poll respondent Jon Glahn, 75, of Camanche.
Julie Roe, 47, of Eldora is a Christian conservative who calls former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee and U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz her top choices. But she, too, sees Trump as a positive force in the race.

"I kind of like the way he has emboldened the rest of the Republican field," she said. "These other candidates tend to follow the same line of thinking that he's brought to the forefront, but he's just bolder in the way that he says them. And he's unafraid of the backlash."
Trump's primary appeal, among his supporters and Republicans overall, is his ability and willingness to "tell it like it is."
Thirty-seven percent of likely caucusgoers and 43% of Trump backers call that the most attractive thing about his candidacy.

"I think he is saying the things that need to be said, although not articulately sometimes, and not courteously. I think he could do a lot better that way," said Robert Kazimour, 80, the retired owner of a trucking company from Cedar Rapids. "But I do think he is touching on topics that need to be discussed."

A narrow plurality of poll respondents — 41% — say Trump cares more about "people like you" than "people like Donald Trump" (40%). Among Trump's supporters though, there's a wide belief that he's looking out for average Americans, with 72% saying he cares more about people like them.

Poll respondents are likewise divided on Trump's political ideology. Forty-one percent call him a "moderate" — which can be a kiss of death in the GOP caucuses — while 35% call him a "conservative." Among his supporters, a 47% plurality identifies him as "conservative" but 30% call him "moderate" and another 11% say he's "liberal."

For many, it's his personality rather than his ideology that makes the difference. A 65% majority of Trump's supporters say they're willing to put their trust in his ability to figure out the issues on the fly and don't need him to be clear about specific policies he'd address if elected.

The Republican ballot is filled with candidates of deep religious faith. But a 57% majority of likely GOP caucusgoers doesn't care that Trump, who says he's a Christian and goes to church, admits he has never has asked God for forgiveness.

That does bother 59% of likely caucusgoers who identify themselves as Christian conservatives. Yet he trails only retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson in support among that group (23 percent for Carson, 16 percent for Trump, followed by Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker and Texas U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz at 12 percent), noted pollster Selzer.

Poll respondents have great confidence in Trump's ability to handle economic and trade matters as president. Eighty-eight percent of likely caucusgoers say international trade would be a strength for Trump; 87% call creating jobs a strength and 84% say he'd be strong in improving middle-class economic conditions.
"I think it's probably going to take someone like Trump who is almost apolitical or a non-politician to restructure the country and get the common people back on track," Kazimour said.
Trump rates worst on working with Congress (51% say that would be a weakness for him as president) and improving race relations (47% call it a weakness).

In a consistent finding, caucusgoers split on whether understanding Iowa would be a strength (46%) or a weakness (45%) for Trump, Selzer said. Among business-oriented establishment caucusgoers, 57% say understanding Iowa would be a strength, as do 58% of those with less than a college degree.

For all the positive views revealed by the poll, though, even Trump's supporters expressed some surprise at his durability as a presidential candidate and wondered whether he could make it all the way to Election Day.

"I'm sure the Republicans will try to kill him," said Glahn, the Trump supporter from Camanche. "After all, the Republican Party is just as crooked as the Democratic Party. They don't want guys like that. They're in it as a business more or less and a lifetime career. They don't want Donald Trump. They'll try to get him out and they'll probably do it, too."
About the poll

The Iowa Poll, conducted Aug. 23-26 for The Des Moines Register and Bloomberg Politics by Selzer & Co. of Des Moines, is based on telephone interviews with 400 registered Iowa voters who say they definitely or probably will attend the 2016 Republican caucuses and 404 registered voters who say they definitely or probably will attend the 2016 Democratic caucuses.

Interviewers with Quantel Research contacted 2,975 randomly selected active voters from the Iowa secretary of state's voter registration list by telephone. Responses were adjusted by age, sex and congressional district to reflect all active voters in the voter registration list. Interviews were administered in English Questions based on the subsamples of 404 likely Democratic caucus attendees or 400 likely Republican caucus attendees each have a maximum margin of error of plus or minus 4.9 percentage points. This means that if this survey were repeated using the same questions and the same methodology, 19 times out of 20, the findings would not vary from the percentages shown here by more than plus or minus 4.9 percentage points. Results based on smaller samples of respondents — such as by gender or age — have a larger margin of error. For additional technical information about this study, contact Michelle Yeoman at myeoman@selzerco.com.
Republishing the copyright Iowa Poll without credit to Bloomberg Politics and The Des Moines Register is prohibited.
DENVER — The private and public sectors battle it out Wednesday as Republican presidential candidates from the business and political worlds meet for their third debate.

In a session devoted to the economy, Donald Trump, Ben Carson and Carly Fiorina are expected to argue that their private-sector experience makes them better bets to handle the economy and the presidency.
The trio will face seven current and former officeholders who say government experience is essential preparation for the Oval Office.
That group features current or former governors — Jeb Bush, John Kasich, Chris Christie and Mike Huckabee — as well as three U.S. senators: Marco Rubio, Ted Cruz and Rand Paul.
Amid the economic policy discussions at the University in Colorado in Boulder on Wednesday night will also be a healthy dose of politics.

Stan Collender, executive vice president at the Qorvis MSLGROUP public affairs firm, said the candidates will be appealing strictly to the Republican base of conservative voters when it comes to issues like federal spending, deficit reduction, free trade and tax cuts.
"These are not economic plans," Collender said. "They're throwing red meat to the primary voters."

The GOP candidates, all of whom have criticized the pace of economic recovery under President Obama, may also be asked about the new budget deal struck by the House Republican leadership. Some of the more conservative members of the House GOP have criticized the proposal.
The main debate starts at 8 p.m. ET and — at the demand of Trump and other candidates — will be limited to two hours.

As with the two previous Republican gatherings, the Colorado event will include a preliminary debate with the lower-polling candidates. The four-person "happy hour" debate will feature Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal, former New York governor George Pataki, South Carolina Sen. Lindsey Graham and former Pennsylvania senator Rick Santorum.
The event — dubbed "Your Money, Your Vote" — is being sponsored by the CNBC financial news network.
The questions will focus on "the key issues that matter to all voters," CNBC said. "Job growth, taxes, technology, retirement and the health of our national economy."

Trump's emphasis on his business career — "I make deals" — helped drive him to the top of Republican polls. But he enters this debate amid signs that he is losing his lead to another outsider candidate, Carson.

The retired neurosurgeon has topped Trump in recent polls in Iowa, which opens the nomination process with caucuses on Feb. 1. A New York Times/CBS News poll out Tuesday shows Carson also edging ahead of Trump among Republicans nationally.
In the debate, Trump can be expected to argue that his business skills would enable him to manage a job-creating economy and negotiate better trade deals.
"People are extremely unhappy with their politicians, including the president, including Congress," Trump said Tuesday on MSNBC. "You look what's going on there, it's a mess."

Carson, a retired neurosurgeon, says he is familiar with the economy through his service on corporate boards and that his experience as a doctor has given him an understanding of government regulations.

Fiorina, former CEO of Hewlett-Packard, has argued that business experience is better than political experience when it comes to dealing with the real-world economy. Fiorina received positive reviews for her performances in the two previous debates.
Opponents say the three "outsider" candidates all bring liabilities to the campaign.

Trump's bullying style will make it harder to work with Congress and with other countries, opponents have said, while Fiorina's dismissal from Hewlett-Packard raises questions about her business acumen. Opponents have also cited Carson's lack of experience with government.
The three senators in the main debate — Rubio of Florida, Cruz of Texas, and Paul of Kentucky — can be expected to discuss their efforts in Congress to rein in federal spending and cut the deficit.
The contingent of governors will likely argue that executive experience with state budgets and dealing with legislators is the best possible preparation for the presidency.
Kasich, who worked at Lehman Brothers between stints as a congressman and governor of Ohio, told Fox News recently he understands how businesses operate.
"I know that they're not going to come to your place and create jobs because you yell at them," he said.
Follow @djusatoday on Twitter.

Election Day 2016 will produce a shattering crash larger than anything the pundits anticipate because the revolutionary economic and social changes occurring in the United States have now pushed both the burgeoning new majority and the conservative Republicans' counterrevolution beyond their tipping points.

The United States is being transformed by revolutions remaking the country at an accelerating and surprising pace. Witness the revolutions in technology, the Internet, big data and energy, though just as important are the tremendous changes taking place in immigration, racial and ethnic diversity, the family, religious observance and gender roles. These are reaching their apexes in the booming metropolitan centers and among millennials.

As the revolutions interact, they are accelerating the emergence of a new America. Consider that nearly 40 percent of New York City's residents are foreign-born, with Chinese the second-largest group behind Dominicans. The foreign-born make up nearly 40 percent of Los Angeles' residents and 58 percent of Miami's. A majority of U.S. households are headed by unmarried people, and, in cities, 40 percent of households include only a single person. Church attendance is in decline, and non- religious seculars now outnumber mainline Protestants. Three-quarters of working-age women are in the labor force, and two-thirds of women are the breadwinners or co- breadwinners of their households. The proportion of racial minorities is approaching 40 percent, but blowing up all projections are the 15 percent of new marriages that are interracial. People are moving from the suburbs to the cities. And in the past five years, two-thirds of millennial college graduates have settled in the 50 largest cities, transforming them.

Shifting attitudes were underscored in this year's Gallup Poll when 60 to 70 percent of the country said gay and lesbian relations, having a baby outside of marriage, sex between an unmarried man and woman, and divorce are all "morally acceptable."
The United States is emerging out of its revolutions as racially blended, immigrant, multinational and multilingual - and diversity is becoming more central to our multicultural identity.

Further, these revolutionary transformations have accelerated the growth of a new majority coalition of racial minorities, single women, millennials and seculars. Together, these groups formed 51 percent of the electorate in 2012, but our analysis of census survey data and exit poll projections indicates that they will comprise fully 63 percent in 2016. With these growing groups each supporting Hillary Clinton by more than 2 to 1 in today's polls, it is fair to say that the United States has reached an electoral tipping point.
The Republican Party's battle to defeat this new majority has reached a tipping point, too. The brand of the Republican Party today has probably not been as tarnished since the Watergate era.

Republicans have joined a ferocious and intensifying decade-long counterrevolution in an attempt to stop this new majority from governing successfully. In 2004, George W. Bush campaign strategist Karl Rove launched the battle for American values when he gave up on the so-called swing voter and worked to engage millions more evangelicals. That has required pouring ever more fuel on the fire – including warning of Armageddon if the liberal Democrats were to govern.

This battle has left the Republicans with mostly married voters, as well as the oldest, most rural and most religiously observant voters in the country. That creates formidable odds against its winning an electoral college majority.

It has also left a Republican Party where three-quarters of its base voters are tea party supporters, evangelicals or religiously observant. That in turn has catapulted to the top of the Republican presidential race candidates who promise to challenge this new America before it's too late.

That this counterrevolution has reached its own tipping point is evident in the shrinking proportion of people who think of themselves as conservative. When Republicans challenged President Obama in the off-year elections of 2010, 46 percent of the country was conservative at the high point. That figure is now 37 percent.

For Republicans, 2016 will prove to be no normal election, because it will confirm that the new America is here and that the counterrevolution has lost. That is why I expect the result to be shattering for the Republican Party as we know it.
But it may not prove to be so shattering for the Republican Party that emerges afterward, or for the republic.

For the GOP, 2016 may look like 1984 did for the Democratic Party. It emerged divided out of a bitter primary, and the Democrats' mainstream candidate, Walter Mondale, lost in a landslide. Afterward, the modernizers got the upper hand. They might well have elected Gary Hart in 1988 and did elect Bill Clinton in 1992.

It is easy to imagine, then, that after the coming shattering election, some Republican leaders will repudiate this campaign's anti-immigrant and anti-Muslim appeals and actively embrace the United States as an immigrant nation. Other leaders might accept the sexual revolution and the new gender roles and work to help the modern working family. Others might embrace again the need for national investment in education and modern infrastructure.
That would allow a different kind of debate within the Republican Party and, perhaps, a different kind of politics in the country.
Stanley B. Greenberg is a Democratic pollster and chief executive of the firm Greenberg Quinlan Rosner Research, and the author of "America Ascendant."
Meetings over the last two days showed the two major parties in Kentucky on two very different trajectories.
About 180 Republicans gathered Saturday in Louisville in a large conference hall to celebrate their victories in the 2015 elections in which they swept five of the seven offices.
Joyful and feeling their oats, Republicans had to move the meeting at the last minute because they needed more space than Lexington’s Campbell House could provide.

Less than 24 hours earlier, about two dozen dispirited and shell-shocked Democrats holed up at state Democratic Party headquarters to talk about the election, how to move forward and – most importantly – how to hold onto the Kentucky House of Representatives.

It's amazing they found time to do that, as they're so busy pointing fingers at everyone from President Barack Obama to Jack Conway, their vanquished gubernatorial nominee, for their losses and fighting over who will control what is left of a party apparatus.
Holding onto the House won’t be an easy task.
The problems for the Democrats are significant and have been growing for years.
They continually must fight the perception of the national Democratic Party, which is far more liberal than the old-school Democrats that are found outside of Louisville, Lexington and Frankfort.

They have difficulty in aligning all of their constituencies – gay, straight, black, white, rural and urban – in a way that doesn’t alienate large segments of their support. Because of that, they’ve found it difficult to promote a cohesive message and it has left them in the last two elections running against Republicans instead of running for office.
In 2014, the message was that Mitch McConnell was bad. This year, their message was that Matt Bevin can’t be trusted.
Moreover, they’ve allowed the Republicans to paint them as anti-coal and have blamed them for the declining industry in Eastern Kentucky.

They’ve been unable or unwilling to fight back by explaining that the industry is dying in Eastern Kentucky not because of Obama – who granted, hasn’t been helpful to the industry – and his environmental policies, but because coal seams there are often less than two-feet thick, making it some of the most expensive coal in the world.
In Wyoming, where coal seams are 100 feet thick, one miner can pull more than 13 times as much coal from the ground as one toiling away in Eastern Kentucky.
Democrats lost the state Senate in 1999 and now it appears that they are set to lose the state House – the only state legislative body in the South their party still controls.
They also face an even bigger hurdle looming ahead:
Money.

McConnell, the U.S. Senate majority leader, has the ability to raise more money than Croesus and without the governor’s mansion – and all the state appointments and state contracts that go along with it. The Democrats don’t have a position of power from where they can launch a major fundraising effort.

The Democratic Party’s greatest hope now appears to rest upon Matt Bevin erring in the same way that Ernie Fletcher did following his election in 2003 – a scandal that brought down his administration and allowed Steve Beshear to grab back the governor’s office for the Democrats.

In the short term, they must focus on winning two house seats being vacated by Mike Harmon and Ryan Quarles, who were elected as state auditor and agriculture commissioner. That could create a bit of momentum for the party and build a tenuous fire wall against the advancing Republicans.
If they don’t, the Republicans may need a bigger location for their party next year. And the Democrats’ meeting might take place in a corner of their headquarters building in Frankfort.
Joseph Gerth can be reached at 502-582-4702 or jgerth@courier-journal.com. Follow him on Twitter at @Joe_Gerth.

Not all of the three-hour Republican presidential candidate debate Wednesday night was about the big issues. There are some other practical elements of being President of the United States that must be addressed, of course.
Yes, we're talking code names.

"You all know that the United States Secret Service uses code names for the president, and his family. Ronald Reagan's code name, for example, was Rawhide, an homage to his performances in Westerns. Nancy Reagan's was Rainbow," moderator Jake Tapper posed as the softball question.
Here's how each of the candidates responded:
Chris Christie: True Heart
John Kasich: Unit One
Scott Walker: Harley
Jeb Bush: Ever Ready
Carly Fiorina: Secretariat
Donald Trump: Humble
Ben Carson: One Nation
Ted Cruz: Cohiba
Marco Rubio: Gator
Mike Huckabee: Duck Hunter
Rand Paul: Justice Never Sleeps

If Republicans are the party of fiscal responsibility, as opposed to those big-spending Democrats, you wouldn’t know it from the GOP candidates’ reckless tax-cut proposals. Donald Trump’s plan would reduce federal revenue by a staggering $10 trillion over 10 years, Marco Rubio’s by $2.4 trillion and Jeb Bush’s by $1.6 trillion, according to analyses by the non-partisan Tax Foundation.

One of the scariest moments in Tuesday’s GOP presidential debate came when Ted Cruz suggested his proposal was more responsible because it would cost only about three-quarters of a trillion dollars over 10 years.

Even worse, these numbers depend on the economic growth the candidates claim their plans will create. Studies and real-world experiments show that big tax cuts don’t reliably spur growth, but they surely wreck budgets.
Candidates always claim they’ll offset revenue losses with spending cuts, yet that promise rarely gets fully detailed, much less fulfilled.
Ironically, the candidates are proposing these plans when the federal deficit is falling, a trend their proposals would reverse.

The candidates are right: The tax code is a mess that needs to be overhauled and simplified. Tax reform will do more harm than good, however, if it explodes deficits and tacks trillions of dollars more onto the national debt.
On TPP, candidates grow away from party’s pro-trade roots
Listening to some of the Republican candidates bash the newly unveiled Trans-Pacific Partnership, one can’t help but conclude that this is not President Reagan’s GOP anymore.

Reagan was unambiguous in his support for trade as a generator of economic growth and global democratization. Most of the presidential aspirants who took to the stage for another debate Tuesday sounded more like a bunch of labor bosses. They claim they are pro-trade in principle, but somehow can’t bring themselves to support the largest, most important trade pact in at least two decades.

As is the case in most endeavors involving hyperbole and simplistic answers, Donald Trump was the leader of this anti-trade pack. He excoriated the Trans-Pacific agreement by claiming that China has gained an unfair trade advantage in recent years — an interesting argument considering that China is frozen out of this deal, which was conceived in part as a check to its ambitions in Asia.

But Trump is not the only one beating the anti-trade drum. Sens. Rand Paul and Ted Cruz both voted against legislation that allowed the trade deal to be finalized. And Cruz, Carly Fiorina, Mike Huckabee and Bobby Jindal are among those who have explicitly opposed the measure. (Jeb Bush, Marco Rubio and Rick Santorum have signaled support.)
The opponents seem to rely mainly on the political argument that if President Obama negotiated it, it must be bad.

If they insist on letting partisanship drive the party away from Reagan and the GOP’s pro-trade roots, maybe they should consider this: Hillary Clinton is against the trade pact, too. Rather than turn their backs on free trade, they should go after the Democratic front-runner for siding with Big Labor and against the American consumers, farmers and exporters who would benefit from the Trans-Pacific deal.
Eliminating Cabinet departments doesn’t eliminate jobs
Someone should tell Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas that if he’s going to say he would eliminate five federal departments and agencies, he should be able to name them.

Cruz could only come up with four during Tuesday’s Republican debate, eliciting instant comparisons to former Texas governor Rick Perry’s infamous “oops” moment during a similar debate four years ago, when he could only name two of his targeted three.
But forgetting a name is not the silliest thing about eliminating departments and agencies. The silliest thing is that it wouldn’t save much money.
When people say they would eliminate a department, in most cases what they mean is that they would merely eliminate the jobs at the top that bind together a number of unrelated parts.

Cruz, for example, wants to get rid of the Commerce Department. So much so that he listed it twice. But the main parts of the department include the Patent and Trademark Office, the Census Bureau and the weather forecasting agencies. Few people seriously want to do away with these. Similarly, the Energy Department is principally composed of agencies that oversee and protect America’s nuclear arsenal.
Don’t be fooled when candidates call for getting rid of departments and agencies — even when they can remember which ones they want to eliminate.

I've been vexed at unreasonable demands from my fellow conservatives that the president submit to our budget demands or we shut the government down. It is irrational, and accusations that the Republican congressional leadership were not real Republicans were exasperating and damaging to the party.

But as details emerge about this budget deal, what is one to think? We agree to eliminate the sequester and budget caps now in exchange for some illusory promise of entitlement reform later. Haven't we seen this movie before? Future cuts never happen. Kill this deal.
— Dennis McLaughlin, Pleasant Hill
Republicans will continue to control the Dutchess County Legislature, but by how great a margin depends on several races that were too close to call.

Former Legislator John Forman, a Republican, had a 19-vote lead over Democrat Tony Sciarrone in District 16 (Fishkill/City of Beacon), the seat being vacated by Democrat and Assistant Minority Leader Alison MacAvery. All results are unofficial.
In District 18 (City of Beacon/Fishkill), incumbent Democrat April Marie Farley was trailing Republican Jerry Landisi by 15 votes.
Incumbent Democrat Joel Tyner had a 57-vote lead over challenger Tom Traudt in District 11 (Rhinebeck/Clinton).
In District 14 (Wappinger), incumbent Democrat Francena I. Amparo had just a 21-vote lead over Republican challenger Ismay Czarniecki.

"I think that this race shows that every vote counts," said Angela Flesland, the Republican Majority Leader who won reelection in District 6 (Town of Poughkeepsie). "There was low turnout and there are so many races that are going to come down to affidavit or absentee ballots."

In unofficial results, Republicans were poised to pick up a seat in District 7 (Hyde Park/Town of Poughkeepsie), where incumbent Democrat Rich Perkins was defeated by Republican challenger William G. Truitt.
In uncontested races, Democrat Barbara-Jeter Jackson of Poughkeepsie and Republicans Dale Borchert (LaGrange) and Marge Horton (East Fishkill) were reelected.

Democrats picked up one seat -- the one formerly held by Chairman Rob Rolison. District 8 (City/Town of Poughkeepsie) will be represented by Democrat Craig Brendli, who defeated Republican Karen A. Johnson.
The terms are for two years and pay a base salary of $15,450.
The county jail was a central issue in the race. Democrats raised questions about the need for a new one and call for more alternatives.
Republicans pointed to recent cost-cutting steps, such has the installation of temporary housing pods, that have been aimed at reducing overtime in the sheriff's office.
It is important that we protect coast

The coast is the reason we are here. It is the beauty and productivity of the ocean, bays, and creeks that has drawn us. This environment now suffers the shadow of a new threat, that of fossil fuel extraction off our coast. President Obama has opened up the mid and south Atlantic coast to exploration for drilling for oil and gas. Permits are now being applied for geophysical exploration that could begin as early as 2017.

According to the Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, 34 species of marine mammals may be impacted by these exploration activities. Six of these are endangered species. From 32,367 to 3,378 individual dolphins and whales per year are estimated to become injured by the activities. The activities are also estimated to disrupt the behavior of over 3 million individual whales and dolphins per year.

Worst of the associated impacts, are those from seismic testing. This method of sensing utilizes extremely loud blasts to search for fossil fuel deposits under the seabed. Seismic blasting can have damaging effects on cetaceans. Whales and dolphins have underwater auditory and sensory systems which are so specialized and highly-developed that they still exceed the current comprehension of scientists. For example, through echolocation, dolphins can detect the shape, position, and size of larger objects from up to six miles away. The impacts to these creatures from continuous, 190-decibel blasts are dangerous and not fully understood.

Impacts to Delaware’s already damaged fisheries would also occur from these exploration activities. Weakfish, Delaware’s once plentiful state fish, are now all but gone. Delaware’s most popular reef fish, tautog, is now overfished. American Eel, once so important in Delaware’s Bays are at their lowest catch in over 50 years. The once-abundant menhaden, american shad, and herring populations have been decimated.

The Atlantic Ocean should not be permitted to undergo a new barrage of impacts from seismic testing the ultimate consequence of which is risky resource extraction. We cannot gamble on a disaster like the Deep Water Horizon off our coast. That oil spill contaminated over 1,000 miles of coastline, caused billions of dollars in damage to fisheries, and caused over $20 billion in damage to the gulf tourist economy.

It is time for those of us who love our coast to act. Contact Delaware’s US Senators and ask that they take the public position that seismic testing for fossil fuel extraction not be permitted in the Atlantic Ocean and that no offshore oil and gas leasing occur. Ask that your representatives to your town or County formulate a resolution to do the same. By taking this position, you will be joining DNREC Secretary David Small, U.S. Rep. John Carney, at least a dozen other U.S. Senators, and elected officials from over eighty towns, cities, and counties. We can still protect the coast we love and we can act now.
Chris Bason
Ocean View
Republicans wasting taxes on politics

House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy recently acknowledged what everyone else in Washington knew: that the House committee investigating the Benghazi terrorist attacks was nothing more than a partisan witch hunt against Hillary Clinton and later, a former committee staffer has come out to say that he was fired for questioning the committee’s focus on Hillary Clinton, even though seven other House investigations have found she did nothing wrong. Not only have Republicans wasted millions in taxpayer funds, but they have politicized the deaths of 4 Americans. This is nothing new for Republicans, whether it be the manipulation of congressional redistricting to favor Republicans or the strict voter ID laws that discriminate against minorities which, surprise, tend to favor Democrats in elections. Republicans use these dirty tactics, because without them, they’d fade into oblivion, and We the People need to stop them from manipulating our democracy.
Alex Russo
Wilmington
Obamacare is too costly
To all you Democrats out there: Will you please tell me once again what’s so affordable about the Affordable Care Act (ObamaCare)?
Once again we learn that whatever the problem, the government is not the solution.

Letter writer hates Democrats

“It’s time for the Monthly Blame Game.” Every month the same letter writer has found a way to blame President Obama, Secretary Hillary Clinton, or any other Democrat.
